cpr.title: CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation)
steps: Ensure the scene is safe.
Check if the person is responsive and breathing.
Call emergency services or ask someone to do so.
Begin chest compressions: 100–120 compressions per minute, pushing hard and fast in the center of the chest.
After 30 compressions, give 2 rescue breaths (if trained and comfortable).
Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until help arrives or the person recovers.

bleeding.title: Severe Bleeding
steps: Apply direct pressure with a clean cloth or bandage.
Elevate the injured limb above heart level, if possible.
If blood soaks through, add another layer—don’t remove the first.
Maintain pressure and apply a pressure bandage.
If bleeding is uncontrollable, consider using a tourniquet (only if trained).
Seek immediate medical help.

burns.title: Burns (All Degrees)
steps: Stop the burning: remove the source.
Cool the burn with clean running water for at least 10 minutes.
Remove jewelry or restrictive items near burn—swelling can occur.
Cover with a clean non-stick dressing or plastic wrap.
Do not apply creams, oils, or ice directly.
Do not burst blisters. Seek medical attention for serious burns.

fractures.title: Suspected Fractures and Sprains
steps: Ensure the scene is safe and calm.
Immobilize the affected area using splints or padded supports.
Use a sling for arm/shoulder injuries.
Apply ice packs wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling.
Keep the injured area elevated if possible.
Seek professional medical care promptly.

choking.title: Choking (Adult & Child)
steps: Ask 'Are you choking?' If they can cough, encourage coughing.
If they can't breathe, speak, or cough, call emergency services.
Perform 5 back blows between the shoulder blades.
Then perform up to 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
Alternate back blows and thrusts until the object is dislodged.
If the person becomes unresponsive, begin CPR.

hypothermia.title: Hypothermia (Extreme Cold)
steps: Move the person to a warm, sheltered area.
Remove wet clothing and dry gently.
Wrap in dry blankets, including head (but not face).
Offer warm (not hot) sweetened drinks if conscious.
Do NOT apply direct heat or massage limbs.
Seek medical help immediately.

heatstroke.title: Heat Exhaustion / Heatstroke
steps: Move to a cool, shaded or air-conditioned location.
Loosen or remove tight clothing.
Cool skin with wet cloths, fans, or misting.
Give sips of cool water unless unconscious or nauseous.
If signs worsen (confusion, fainting), treat as heatstroke:
Call emergency services and begin rapid cooling—immerse in cool water or apply ice packs to groin/armpits/neck.

shock.title: Shock
steps: Have the person lie down on their back.
Elevate legs about 12 inches (if no spinal injury).
Keep them warm and comfortable with blankets.
Do not give food or drink.
Monitor breathing and consciousness.
Call emergency services right away.

poisoning.title: Poisoning (Ingestion / Chemical)
steps: Ensure the area is safe and avoid further exposure.
Identify the substance if possible.
Do NOT induce vomiting unless directed by poisoning control.
Rinse skin or eyes with water if contact occurred.
Call poison control center or emergency services immediately.

electric_shock.title: Electric Shock
steps: Turn off the electricity at the source—or use non‑conductive object to separate victim from current.
Do NOT touch the victim while they’re still in contact.
Check responsiveness and breathing; call emergency services.
Start CPR if unresponsive and not breathing.
Cover burns with clean, dry, non-stick dressing.
Treat for shock and keep warm until help arrives.

drowning.title: Drowning / Near-Drowning
steps: Ensure scene safety; remove the person from water.
Check responsiveness and breathing immediately.
Call emergency services and start CPR if needed.
Place in recovery position if breathing returns.
Prevent hypothermia: cover with blankets.
Even if recovered, seek medical evaluation—delayed complications can occur.

animal_bites.title: Animal or Insect Bites & Stings
steps: Clean the wound with soap and water.
Apply an antiseptic.
Cover with a sterile dressing.
For insect stings, remove stinger carefully and apply a cold pack.
Monitor for signs of allergic reaction (hives, swelling, difficulty breathing).
If severe, administer epinephrine (if available) and call emergency services.

head_injury.title: Head Injury
steps: Keep the person still and calm.
Check for responsiveness and breathing.
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling.
Do not move the person if you suspect spinal injury.
Call emergency services if there is confusion, vomiting, or unconsciousness.

spinal_injury.title: Suspected Spinal Injury
steps: Do not move the person unless in immediate danger.
Keep the head, neck, and back in alignment.
Stabilize the head with towels or hands on each side.
Call emergency services immediately.
Monitor breathing and be prepared to start CPR if needed.

crush_injury.title: Crush Injury
steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Do not attempt to lift heavy debris alone.
If safe, control bleeding with pressure.
If the limb has been trapped for more than 15 minutes, do not release without medical help (risk of toxic shock).
Keep the person calm and monitor for shock.

amputation.title: Amputation
steps: Call emergency help immediately.
Apply firm pressure to stop bleeding using a clean cloth or bandage.
Wrap the amputated part in moist sterile gauze, place in a sealed plastic bag, then place that bag in cold water (not directly on ice).
Label the part with the person's name and time.
Treat the person for shock until help arrives.

trapped_under_debris.title: Person Trapped Under Debris
steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Do not move heavy debris unless trained and safe to do so.
Talk to the victim to reassure them.
Provide water if they are alert and it's safe.
Check for bleeding or breathing difficulties and assist only if safe to do so.

hypoxia.title: Low Oxygen (Hypoxia from Smoke or Dust Inhalation)
steps: Move the person to fresh air immediately.
Loosen tight clothing.
Check breathing—begin CPR if necessary.
If conscious, keep them calm and seated.
Seek urgent medical attention.

chemical_exposure.title: Chemical Exposure (from Flood or Industrial Damage)
steps: Avoid exposure yourself—wear gloves/mask if available.
Flush affected skin or eyes with clean water for at least 15 minutes.
Remove contaminated clothing carefully.
Cover with a sterile dressing if needed.
Call poison control or emergency services.

flood_related_illness.title: Contaminated Water / Flood-Related Illness
steps: Give only clean bottled or boiled water.
Clean wounds with antiseptic to prevent infection.
Watch for signs of diarrhea, vomiting, or fever.
Avoid contact with flood water if possible.
Seek medical care for persistent symptoms.

panic_attack.title: Panic Attack (Psychological First Aid)
steps: Speak calmly and reassure the person they are safe.
Encourage slow, deep breathing.
Move to a quieter, less stimulating environment if possible.
Stay with the person and offer emotional support.
Seek mental health support after the disaster if needed.

dehydration.title: Dehydration
steps: Move the person to a shaded or cool area.
Give frequent small sips of clean water.
Use oral rehydration salts if available.
Monitor for signs of worsening condition (confusion, fainting).
Seek medical help if severe symptoms appear.

hypoglycemia.title: Low Blood Sugar (Hypoglycemia)
steps: Give a sugary snack, drink, or glucose tablets immediately.
If unconscious, do not give anything by mouth—call emergency help.
Once alert, provide a balanced meal or snack.
Monitor closely and avoid further delay in food intake.
Seek medical care if symptoms recur.

tsunami_escape_injury.title: Injuries During Tsunami or Rapid Evacuation
steps: Stop any visible bleeding with direct pressure.
Treat open wounds to prevent infection.
Support sprains or fractures with improvised splints.
Check for signs of shock (pale, cold, rapid breathing).
Seek help as soon as it’s safe to do so.

burns_in_wildfire.title: Burns in Wildfires
steps: Move the person away from fire or smoke.
Cool burns with water for at least 10 minutes.
Do not apply ointments or ice.
Cover with clean, non-stick dressing or cloth.
Treat for shock and seek medical help quickly.
